text: (upbeat music)

- [Shiftee] Music creation
is incredibly complex.
Many people try to make music
and a lot of folks fail.
(upbeat music)
The reason why they fail
is not because they don't have drive
or desire or good taste,
it's because they don't have
the ability to get their ideas out.
- [Werner Vogels] Our planet and our civilizations
are changing faster than ever before.
Join me as I travel the globe
talking to start-up founders
using technologies to make our world
more interesting, accessible, and livable.
These are the entrepreneurs
that are creating the future
we will live in.
This is Now Go Build.
(upbeat drum music)
Amsterdam, I love this city, my city.
I'm Dutch but I'm from Amsterdam.
You see a stunning city filled with
art, music, architecture, food,
and canals and bicycles everywhere.
I see home.
When I left the Netherlands,

Amsterdam was just
beginning to find its way
in the technology world.

Today, Amsterdam has
become a thriving tech hub
with a fast-growing, start-up scene,

a scene that has inherited the
city's centuries-old practice
of world-changing innovation.
Throw in the artists and musicians
that have always found their place here,
and you can see why I believe
there's no place like Amsterdam.
Is it always good to come back
and visit my old home,
drink my favorite drinks,
and eat my favorite food.
But this time, I'm in Amsterdam
for one of my favorite gatherings,
the Amsterdam Dance Event.

ADE is a celebration for
electronic music and technology,
two things I can't do without.

People come from around
the world for conferences,
to discover new music technologies,
and of course, to dance.
I decided to bring together
some of the technologists in town,
and one of my favorite EDM artists
in my local pub, the Black Dog.

We met to discuss the
evolving relationship
between music and technology.
When you think about music,
software's not the first thing
that comes to your mind, is it?
How has creation of music changed
by the introduction of software?
- I would say one thing it's done
is it's leveled the playing field

and made it way more accessible
for more people where
from being a DJ to being a producer,
you used to have to have so much gear
that was expensive, hard to come by.

And if you wanted to
play a synthesizer sound,
you'd have to own a synthesizer
and so software makes it so
there isn't this cost-gear barrier.

- We've taken the idea of
software as an instrument

and expanded it to being
software as a connector.

So when two artists need
to work together better,

we provide software for that
collaboration to happen,
sort of in the background.

And we go all the way
to our sounds product
in which we make a marketplace,
an artist to artist marketplace,

for people to connect and
share sounds and samples
that they're using in productions today.
So software's really,
not just connecting people,

but blurring the lines between
instrument and technology.
- In the music industry,
it's interesting to see there's still
this attachment to some gear, so yeah,
we're going towards software to make music

but I think there is
this moment of creativity

when you can have that direct
contact with the instrument,

and the controller or the
hardware become the instrument.

And I think the good
integration of software

within the hardware to
make the workflow seamless,
is really what we are shooting for.
(electronic music)
- So walk us a little bit through
a typical creation process.

- Typically, I'm sent
the beats by producers
and what I like to do is
before I listen too much to each thing
and get too stuck in it,
I want to just sit with my laptop,

plug everything in, hit
record, just from the go,

'cause I feel like whatever
comes to you instinctively
is probably the best it's gonna be.
- What's the role with technology
in the whole collaborative process?
- Well, firstly,

I no longer have to be in
the same room as somebody.

Previously if we wanted
to make a track together,

we had to meet up, go in a
studio, and make a track.

But I have collaborators
now all over the world
and we're sharing files and sharing ideas

in all kinds of different
ways from just like,

emailing STEMs to even
face-timing each other

while one of us is working
on a track and say,
like, turn that up or like,
oh, yeah, I like that over there.
It's really opened up the world
for potential collaborations.

- Is there still a role
for the traditional studio?
- I'm all a big fan of removed work
and collaboration from all over the world
because it makes it easier
but this human connection of having
several artists in the room

and having this connection
in the creation process
is very important,

to still have this moment
where you get together.
- I mean, there's no substitute currently
for being in the same room

and having that immediate
feedback of someone

playing a lick on the
keys and the singer going,
oh, I like that.

There isn't really an
equivalent in the Cloud.
- I promise you we're working on it.
- Thank you, please.

I would like to never interact
with another human if--
- Well, actually--
- I take that back.

Yeah, I mean there is this
sense in which the Cloud
not replacing real life collaborations
but being like another party in the room

where when you have that
moment of inspiration together
and you're like, oh we need an orchestra,
then you don't have to go then like--
(laughing)
Do you know any tuba players?
I don't know any tuba players.

- They're very expensive.
- You load in
the orchestra plug-in.
(electronic music)
(vocalizing)
- [Werner] Where's the drum set?
- All of this is a drum set.

- It's in the system.
- Okay.
- Yeah, yeah, every instrument right here.
- [Werner] Cool, so, keyboards?

- Keyboard, the keyboard
is any virtual instrument
or sample that I want to manipulate,
I can manipulate it here.

So that's why when we
say the drum set is here,

it really can be where
this can be the kick,

this can be the snare,
this can be the hi-hats,

and I can play everything
I need with this.
- It looks like a keyboard
but it's just an API, just an interface,
to the instruments that you have there.
The turntable is not really a turntable,
you use it for something else
and just play it backwards, I assume.

- Yeah, so any sound, I can
manipulate it like this.
This is also just,
this is a controller,
the machine pad is a controller,
this has become a controller too

and it's just, how can
you touch your sounds?

- Yeah, it's not really that
you're playing the audio
that's on the final, right?
- No.

So it's used to control
literally any sound

that's ever been recorded
or that we record.
So actually we could grab...
Yeah.
So.
♪ Go, go, go, go, go! ♪
(scratch sounds)
♪ Go build ♪

- Can you talk a bit about the
distribution part, as well?
How has that changed over time?
- Basically, distribution,

as in getting your songs
out to the general public

has changed because
consumption essentially comes

from YouTube or some type
of subscription platform,
Apple Music, Spotify, et cetera.

The difference in getting
your music out there
isn't really about where you can find it,

'cause really you can
find it almost anywhere,

it's more about how you
get someone to hear it
because if you are placed on
a Apple Music new music playlist
or Spotify Discover Weekly,

it can dramatically change
your career as an artist.

So the algorithms essentially
have an enormous power

and also responsibility
to the culture of music.

I mean, you're talking
50, 60, 70 million people
played a different song,
that's a huge difference,
huge, huge, huge difference.
- Yeah, because in the past,
I mean, we saw this shift happening where

get control towards the
musician instead of the label.

But if there's other
gatekeepers now suddenly
that are algorithms are the gatekeepers,
you should try to avoid that as well
because otherwise you start making music
to please the gatekeepers.
- Oh yeah, for sure.
- To get past the gate.

- And it's very tough to
make significant income
off of these streaming services
unless you get on like a huge playlist.
Like, I think, last I checked,
10,000 streams was like forty dollars.
And so, it...
(Werner laughs)
We'll get a dinner.
(all laughing)

And so, in terms of
actually making a living,

one thing is it makes artists
look for other avenues
but the current system is certainly
not doing justice to artists
in terms of their music having value.
- [Werner] How do you make your money?

- Yeah, so, I've always had a
bit of a business head on me

and I knew that I, as a vocalist
and as a female vocalist,
that I could record myself and then,
kind of set up a business from it.

So once I started bringing
out vocal sample packs

which was sort of another
line of session work
for me, really,

I just found a lot of people
were reaching out to me

through the vocal sample
packs that I had made.

It was less of a
collaboration and being like,

you tell me what you want and
I can create that for you,
or I can craft that for you,
and then I would charge for that service.

Over time, I felt like I
wanted to be more creative
and so now I'll work with people,

like sometimes you have
to do that for free

if you're trying to get into
that record label or whatever.
But yeah, for me, a big part of it
was the vocal sample packs.
- If you're a music creator
and you're not like a superstar,
you have to sort of pursue
a bunch of different revenue streams.

And what's interesting
about Splice in particular

is that now there's a
way for that community
to sell to each other.
- Artists have long been exploited
by the people in charge of distribution,
from publishers to record labels,
to promoters and ticket distributors.
It has always been difficult
for musicians to take control
of the business side of their arts,
the finances, and the distribution.
But new technologies and the Cloud
are rapidly changing that power dynamic.

Maarten Bloemers, the CEO
of Amsterdam start-up, GUTS,
is in town for ADE.

In part by using Ethereum's
favor of blockchain,
Guts is tackling the problem
of ticket scalping and price gouging.

On the way to one of the
opening dance events,
by boat of course,

we found some time to
talk about the problem
this former lawyer has set out to solve.
So why is scalping a problem?

- Well, in Holland, it's
actually a big problem.
So they buy up a bulk of tickets for cheap

and then they sell them
off for higher prices.
And the mark-ups are insane,
can reach up to 700% markup.
There are cases known that the scalpers,
they make more money of the whole event,

than all the artists
or everybody involved.

- So, there must be some
smartness in the tickets.
So tell me about that.

- Basically what we do is we
make the ticket truly digital,

so normally, the tickets are
distributed via like a PDF,

so you can duplicate it,
it's tangible, basically.

What we do is we create
a truly digital ticket.

We do that because our QR code
refreshes every 15 seconds,
it's not a sequence,

it actually asks a new
QR code every 15 seconds

which means that screenshots
and duplicating is impossible.
- How much do you rely on
the smart contract part of Ethereum?
- Very, very little.
And it keeps getting smaller every month.
- So, I'd like to make a case then
that blockchain is not necessary here.

I think what you're looking
for is immutability.
- Yep.
- And transparency, of course.
Then looking at blockchain, I think,
all the stories that I've heard

and so now, people looking
for solutions on blockchain

can actually be solved through
a much simpler solution.
Also because we know much better
how to engineer those solutions.
I think decentralizing,
especially with decentralized trust,

things become much harder
to debunk, to build,
and things like that.
- Absolutely.

So we made a promise we're
gonna do it on blockchain,

so we'll try to proceed as
far and as good as we could.
But when push comes to shove,
and it seems useless--
- Your solution is better, yep.
- We'll go for it, of course.
- Good, okay.
- I'm a pragmatic man.

- When was the last time you
bought a non-digital ticket?

- I think it was actually last
week for a festival, yeah.
- Well, it still happens.

- Yeah, world domination
is a long way to go, yeah.
(piano music)

- How much work is
configuration for you, Shiftee?
- I would say at this point in my career,

probably like 90% of
my time is preparation.
It's like getting all the settings ready

and getting all the files
prepped the way that I like them,
getting everything talking to each other,

as opposed to actually standing
up and moving a record.

- Does that mean that the
creator has changed as well?
They're probably much more technologist.
- Oh yeah, I mean,
I'm programming midi mappings in Traktor
for hours on hand
and last night in anticipation of today,
I'm diagramming routing.
No, there's a technical learning curve
for sure that comes into it.

- That's why you needed a
math degree from Harvard
to be able to--
- I didn't know I needed it,
but now I have it.
- You know what's interesting though?
And this is something where technology,
specifically Cloud technology,
should be doing a better job for artists.
The era of feeling like,
oh, am I gonna get past the algorithm?
Can I build a social media following?
Can I even figure out how this knob

connects to this knob to
make the sound that I want?

We, as technologists, I feel
we have a responsibility

to connect artists and
to use the technology
so that the artists have leverage.
The artists are the one that got us here,
we should be giving them technology
so that they can take us to places
we haven't even possibly imagined.

- [Shiftee] And do you
want it to loop after that
or do you want to just go--
- Um, yeah, let it loop a couple times.
- [Shiftee] Okay, just on that one part.
- Yes.
Yes.
- [Shiftee] Okay, cool.
♪ Replenish me so ♪
♪ You gave me life ♪
♪ You gave me ♪
♪ You gave me life ♪
♪ You gave me reason ♪
♪ You gave me ♪
♪ You make me so happy ♪
- Is there a path towards, let's say,
automatic music generation?

- Sure, there definitely
is a path towards it.

It's very easy to see how
autonomous driving could work,
you could almost feel it,
you can get behind the wheel of a car
and see what it's gonna be like
'cause you kind of understand

what autonomous driving
is going to feel like.

When it comes to music that
is generated by a computer,

I feel like we're in
very, very early stages.

Every time I've given
a piece of technology
that I built to work with
or I believe is interesting to an artist,
they tend to change it to something
that I could have never possibly imagined.
- Can part of the process be automated?

Let's say, automatically
generating a drum pack.
- [Shiftee] Yeah.
- [Werner] You've figured out the melody,
now you need a drum track underneath that
but you let it generate for you.
- Yeah 'cause I think, then,
there's also an element of choice.
Any time you're using samples
or any kind of automated anything,

the artists working on
it has a choice to say,
I like that or I don't like that.
I love when I'm working on a track
for something to pop up and be like,

hey, your drums stink, you
gotta change your drums.
Or like, we need a bass line.
I would enjoy that and I could be like,
all right, okay, you're right or not,
but it's not bad to just have
extra options and extra choices.

- Or where the software gives
you the feedback saying like,
if you do this, you're not going
to make more than forty dollars.
- That'd be funny.
(laughing)
- The way I envisage it is probably
there's a place for fully automated music
in certain circumstances, I'm with you,
I think it makes a lot of sense,
but I think the interesting part is,

it doesn't replace the
artist creating music.
That's really where we want to go
and some part of that will be done
by more technology to assist
and to make choices for you,
and to be able to do midi mapping for you
so you don't have to do it.
But it's just giving you more time
to be able to create.

I really think if we go
back to autonomous driving
and automated, generated music,
I think in both case,

we are gonna see a world
where both scenarios
are going to lead at the same time.
And of course, it's much more complicated

with autonomous driving
because of the whole,
you're not going to kill anyone by music,
it might make you in a very bad mood
but we're not gonna kill anyone.
You might end up killing someone,
that's a different story.
- You can kill a party.
- Yeah, sure.

- After you think about
innovation and things like that,

you all think about
these new, glitzy things,

or things that people have
never heard about before,

but sometimes innovation
is all about looking at,

what are the things that will
never change for my customers?

And the more you innovate
over those processes

underneath that, you'll benefit
your customers for forever.
Is there an equivalent of that in music?
Things that will never change?

- The music's gotta be dope,
like whatever the process is,
whatever the tools are,

when it comes out of
wherever, however you hear it,

if it doesn't move you, if
it doesn't move the audience,
it doesn't matter.

- So where music is intended
to create an emotion.
- Yep.

- And that's something
that will never change.
(upbeat music)
The job of technologists at its core
is to be creative,
to solve problems,
and to remove obstacles.
To create more innovative ways

to clear the path for
the human experience.
In this last year,
traveling for Now Go Build,

you've seen people
leveraging new technologies

to enable everything from
language learning for refugees,
to access to finance for farmers

that have been left behind
by the world's banks,
and even redefining access to healthcare
for the most vulnerable.
And here, at ADE,
it is just as exciting to see the role
that technology is playing
in removing the obstacles
between the song in the musician's head
and the wall of sound

that helps us do one
more very human thing,
dance.
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
(upbeat music)
